tossups.question: The author of the Perry Mason detective stories, Erle Stanley Gardner, published under a pen name with this letter twice followed by “Fair.” Another author with this double initial set his works in the Hundred Acre Woods, and in an introduction to a novel named for this letter, the author finds this letter on a piece of cloth in a pile of old papers in the (*) Salem Custom House. When the protagonist of that novel dies, her tombstone reads, “On a field, sable, (this letter), gules,” and earlier in that novel, Pearl is unusually fascinated with this letter, which the protagonist placed on her dress as public punishment for her infidelity. For 10 points, name this letter of the alphabet, a scarlet example of which is embroidered on Hester Prynne’s dress in a Hawthorne novel.

The “Transcendental Aesthetic” section of Kant’s Critique of Pure Reason defines this thing as the “form of pure intuition” corresponding to the “inner sense.” In the eleventh book of St. Augustine’s [au-GUS-tin’s] Confessions, he struggles to grasp this concept but eventually concludes that God must exist outside of it. J. M. E. McTaggart’s work about the (*) unreality of this concept argues that an absolute form of it is self-contradictory and that a “B-theory” of this concept implies its tenselessness. A-theorists of this thing believe it flows along a single causal line. For 10 points, give this concept studied in the fields of Presentism and Eternalism, which Aristotle in his work Physics defines as “a number of change with respect to the before and after.”

A mistranslation of the ancient Greek work History of Animals led to the naming of a mouth structure of a class within this phylum as “Aristotle’s lantern.” A class within this phylum can projectile-vomit its organs and is called Holothuroidea, and ambulacral grooves in this phylum connect the ampulla to the (*) madreporite. Classes in this phylum of the simplest deuterostomes include the feathery Crinoidea, or sea lilies, as well as one that most clearly exhibits its pentaradial symmetry, Asteroidea. This phylum is known for its water vascular system and tube feet. For 10 points, name this phylum containing species able to regenerate tissue, which includes sea cucumbers and sea stars.

One text by this man tells of a man from a family of high status and an unblemished record who was immediately put to death along with his children for treason. Another by this man goes into depths about the moral depravity of an opposing army, sarcastically calling them a “splendid army.” This man ended one speech with an invocation to (*) Jupiter requesting eternal punishments for all enemies of good men, and describes a group of people as desperate, ruined criminals who were gathering in the jaws of Etruria. The first of a set of speeches by this man famously asks when the Senator will cease abusing the audiences patience, and when he will bring an end to his unbridled audacity. For 10 points, name this Roman consul and orator of the Catiline Orations.

This painting’s artist later restretched the canvas and added a white substrate border among a series of colored dots that complement adjacent colors. The Marxist philosopher Ernest Bloch described this painting as a “single mosaic of boredom.” In the background of this painting, a blonde girl in an orange dress runs toward a (*) wooded area to the right, and behind a small girl in a white dress clinging to her mother, a man plays a bugle. In the foreground of this painting, a black dog sniffs the ground behind a reclining man in a sleeveless orange shirt smoking a pipe. For 10 points, name this painting with a monkey on a leash and women holding parasols, a large pointillistic work set on the bank of the River Seine by Georges Seurat.
tossups.answer: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte [or Un dimanche après-midi à l'Île de la Grande Jatte; accept either underlined portion] <McMaken>
tossups.answer_formatted: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte [or Un dimanche après-midi à l'Île de la Grande Jatte; accept either underlined portion]
acceptable: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte
Un dimanche après-midi à l'Île de la Grande Jatte

tossups.question: This man analyzed the literati within the officialdom in his work The Religion of China: Confucianism and Taoism. This man described the three “ideal types” of leadership as charismatic, traditional, and legal in a work that described the state as the "only human community which lays claim to the monopoly on the legitimated use of physical force;” that work is the 1919 essay (*) Politics as a Vocation. This sociologist lamented how the "cloak" of care for external goods had become an "iron cage" of bureaucratic rationality, and he also argued that Calvinism influenced the development of market economies. For 10 points, name this German author of Economy and Society and The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism.

This man led a volunteer army force late in his life, resulting in him being elected to the National Assembly of Dijon, a position from which he quickly resigned; that force was called the Army of the Vosges. This man also fought in the Uruguayan Civil War against the forces of Manuel Oribe and Juan Manuel de Rosas, and in yet another war, this man also led a unit called the (*) “Hunters of the Alps,” winning a decisive battle at Bezzecca. At the Battle of Volturno, this man succeeded in conquering the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies through the Expedition of a Thousand, but ended up cooperating with his enemy Count di Cavour so that Victor Emmanuel II could be king. For 10 points, name this leader of the Redshirts during the Risorgimento who sought to unify Italy.

These entities are measured using units called sverdrups. El Niño Southern Oscillation affects one these entities by lowering the thermocline and the upper boundary of the shadow zone, ultimately disrupting local upwelling; that specific entity is named after Alexander von Humboldt. In a process known as (*) Ekman transport, the Coriolis force results in these entities having a net direction of transport ninety degrees to the wind direction. These entities are classified into surface and deep types, the latter of which is driven by thermohaline circulation, and they combine in large bodies of water to form large rotating systems called gyres. For 10 points, name these large flows of water that circulate water throughout the Earth’s oceans.
tossups.answer: ocean currents [prompt on partial answer; do not accept or prompt on tides] <Jin>
tossups.answer_formatted: ocean currents [prompt on partial answer; do not accept or prompt on "tides"]

tossups.question: Two of the most well-known musical themes in this opera were first written when its composer set to music five poems by the speculated love interest Mathilde Wesendonck [VAY-zen-DONK]. In the third act of this opera, Kurwenal [kur-vay-nall] and Melot are both killed, and the prelude to its first act begins with the strings playing an A up to an F, down to an E, then a (*) titular chord consisting of the notes F, B, D-sharp, and G-sharp. This opera ends with the heroine singing the “Liebestod,” or “love death,” aria; that character is an Irish maid who was kidnapped as a bride for King Marke. For 10 points, name this Richard Wagner [REE-kard VAHG-ner] opera in which the two title characters fall in love after drinking a magic potion.
tossups.answer: Tristan und Isolde [or Tristan and Isolda or Tristran and Ysolt or basically anything that sounds like a slurred or badly mangled version of that title] <McMaken>
tossups.answer_formatted: Tristan und Isolde [or Tristan and Isolda or Tristran and Ysolt or basically anything that sounds like a slurred or badly mangled version of that title]
acceptable: basically anything that sounds like a slurred
badly mangled version of that title

tossups.question: A portion of grp75 serves as a chaperone for the tether of calcium 2+ ion channels linking this structure to the endoplasmic reticulum. In the inner membrane of this structure, the Q cycle describes the oxidation and reduction of Coenzyme Q10 between ubiquinol and ubiquinone. That cycle occurring in Complex III [“three”] of this structure reduces (*) cytochrome c in an intermediate step, and that heme protein transfers single electrons and is released from this structure during apoptosis. The electron transport chain in this organelle results in the production of adenosine triphosphate, or ATP. For 10 points, name this organelle that is the powerhouse of the cell.

In some versions, this man lies buried on the banks of the Numicius River, and in others, the river cleansed him of his mortal bits, deifying him as Jupiter Indiges. While fighting, this man is struck on the hip with a boulder and almost dies. After Diomedes fights this man a second time, (*) Apollo leaves a fake copy of him on the battlefield and takes him to shelter. In another story about him, his helmsman Palinurus is put to sleep and falls off the boat. When leaving the underworld, this man is confronted with an ivory gate and one of horn, and he chooses the ivory one. This hero was able to enter the underworld by retreaving a golden bough for the Cumean Sybil. For 10 points, name this Dardanian hero, the progenitor of the Roman kings.

American conductor Gunther Schuller offers a musical analysis on the unique solo improvisation techniques exhibited in a work whose title contains this word followed by “seven.” Another piece with this word in the title is notable for its use of aksak meter, grouping beats into three measures of 2, 2, 2, 3 and one measure of 3, 3, 3; that piece is called “[this word] (*) Rondo à la Turk.” A song on an album whose name contains this adjective is characterized by alternating sections in D Dorian mode and E-flat Dorian mode; that album titled for this color is by Miles Davis. For 10 points, name this adjective used to describe a European river in a waltz by Johann Strauss II, as well as a rhapsody by George Gershwin.
tossups.answer: blue [accept “Blue 7,” “Blue Rondo à la Turk,” Kind of Blue, By the Beautiful Blue Danube, Rhapsody in Blue] <Jin>
tossups.answer_formatted: blue [accept “Blue 7,” “Blue Rondo à la Turk,” Kind of Blue, By the Beautiful Blue Danube, Rhapsody in Blue]
acceptable: “Blue 7,” “Blue Rondo à la Turk,” Kind of Blue, By the Beautiful Blue Danube, Rhapsody in Blue

tossups.question: The keynote speaker of this event was Senator Daniel Inouye from Hawaii. A report on this event was titled the Rights in Conflict. In this event, a Connecticut senator denounced the “Gestapo tactics in the street” as he endorsed George McGovern. That senator was Abraham Ribicoff. One riot surrounding this event was on TV for 17 minutes and included the crowd chanting, (*) “The whole world is watching.” In this event, Jerry Rubin nominated a farm animal named Pigasus for the presidency. For 10 points, name this convention which nominated Hubert Humphrey, but is better known for Richard Daley’s response to mass protests, which included the violent tactics of the Chicago police.

One comic character in this play says that his hands are trembling from not playing billiards for a long time, while another is a child of circus performers and performs card tricks and ventriloquism at a party. One of the characters in this play is reminded of her son’s death when that son’s former tutor unexpectedly shows up at her house. That tutor is nicknamed the (*) “eternal student” for his university studies and is named Peter Trofimov. At the end of this play, the servant Firs is locked inside a house, presumably to die, after the wealthy Lopakhin attends an auction and buys the childhood residence of Madame Ranevsky. For 10 points, name this play that ends with the title estate being cut down with axes, written by Anton Chekhov.

On the first night of this battle, the generals of the defending force were at a party hosted by Admiral Stark. Fortifications were sent to the nearby town of Dalny prior to this battle, which was incited by a surprise nighttime torpedo attack by Admiral Togo that took out two Russian battleships. Diplomatic ties were cut between (*) Russia and Japan two days before this 1904 battle, which was named for the then-Russian naval base at the tip of the Liaodong Peninsula in Manchuria. For 10 points, name this largely inconclusive naval battle which is often considered the first battle of the Russo-Japanese War.

After the appearance of three stars in the sky at the end of this holiday, the havdalah is recited over a cup of wine. Meals on this holiday begin with the blessing of the lechem mishneh, two loaves of bread that symbolize a double portion of manna. A person who observes all the mitzvot associated with this holy day is given the adjective (*) shomer, which includes the prohibition of activities such as plowing, baking, weaving, and writing two or more letters. This holiday is the first mentioned in the Tanakh, since God observed it first after finishing six days of creation. For 10 points, name this day of rest observed by Jews on the seventh day of the week.

A 1937 extended version of this experiment revealed that state transitions could be induced using RF fields in a process influential to the development of MRI machines known as a Rabi oscillation. In 1927, Phipps and Taylor reproduced this experiment using hydrogen atoms instead of atoms of (*) silver. A sulfur-containing cigar was used to visualize the two spots on the detector in this experiment which provides the paradigm for understanding quantum observation. In this experiment, beams in an inhomogeneous magnetic field split due to intrinsic angular momentum. For 10 points, name this doubly-eponymous experiment which showed that electrons have quantized spin.

In the second part of this work, the innkeeper Gaius explains the symbolic meaning of supper and compares “hard texts” to nuts. A character who is exposed by the protagonist of this work is the son of Say-Well and Mrs. Talk-About-The-Right Things. In the first part of this work, the protagonist is asked, “Whence came you, and whither are you bound?" by (*) Apollyon while in the Slough [rhymes with “cow”] of Despond, where the protagonist sinks in the mire under his doubts and sins until he is pulled up by the character Help and led to the Wicket Gate. This work’s title refers to Christian’s journey from the City of Destruction to the Celestial City. For 10 points, name this very early English allegorical novel by John Bunyan.
tossups.answer: The Pilgrim's Progress from This World to That Which is to Come: Delivered under the Similitude of a Dream Wherein is Discovered, the Manner of his Setting Out, his Dangerous Journey, and Safe Arrival at the Desired Countrey [give someone 20 points if they really can pull off that whole title] <McMaken>
tossups.answer_formatted: The Pilgrim's Progress from This World to That Which is to Come: Delivered under the Similitude of a Dream Wherein is Discovered, the Manner of his Setting Out, his Dangerous Journey, and Safe Arrival at the Desired Countrey [give someone 20 points if they really can pull off that whole title]
acceptable: The Pilgrim's Progress from This World to That Which is to Come: Delivered under the Similitude of a Dream Wherein is Discovered, the Manner of his Setting Out, his Dangerous Journey, and Safe Arrival at the Desired Countrey

tossups.question: A group of civil servants called the “Kindergarten” of a commissioner involved in this war helped with reconstruction after its conclusion. The conditions following this war were investigated by Emily Hobhouse, leading to the establishment of the Fawcett Commission. Those conditions were the result of scorched-earth tactics used by (*) Lord Kitchener as well as the first use of concentration camps during this conflict. This war included a 217-day siege battle for the town of Mafeking, and it was ended in 1902 with the signing of the Treaty of Vereeniging. For 10 points, name this conflict between the United Kingdom and a group of Afrikaans-speaking inhabitants of what is now South Africa.
tossups.answer: Second Boer War [prompt on Boer War, South African War, or Anglo-Boer War] <McMaken>
tossups.answer_formatted: Second Boer War [prompt on Boer War, South African War, or Anglo-Boer War]

tossups.question: F. Scott Fitzgerald hated this thing because he said it “is like laughing at your own joke.” When this thing follows an integer n, it is asymptotically equal to the square root of two pi n times the quantity n over e to the n, according to an approximation named for James Stirling. In theatre, this thing is included in titles of shows that have titular songs, such as (*) Mamma Mia! and Oklahoma!, and in chess, two of these things denote an excellent move. The International Phonetic Alphabet uses this symbol to represent a postalveolar click sound, and in computing, this thing is called a “bang” and denotes a logical negation. For 10 points, name this symbol which mathematically denotes a factorial and which in English is used as a punctuation mark after an interjection.

Keweenaw Peninsula in this state was the site of the first copper boom in American history. Part of this state’s international border runs through Lake St. Clair, which lies northeast of this state’s largest city. A ban on motor vehicles in this state’s (*) Mackinac Island makes it a top tourist destination, along with this state’s winter sports hub of Traverse City. Residents of cities like Sault Ste. Marie [soo saint ma-REE] and Marquette in the Upper Peninsula of this state are affectionately known as Yoopers. For 10 points, name this Great Lakes state, with its capital at Lansing.

bonuses.leadin: This man created a work which depicts an apple with the words “this is not an apple” over it. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Belgian surrealist who also made works such as Golconda and The Menaced Assassin.
In addition to This is Not an Apple, Magritte also painted this work that has the phrase, “This is not a pipe” written in French.
Another of Magritte’s most influential paintings is this painting which depicts a daytime street and a single lit street-lamp.

bonuses.leadin: In this dystopian book, humans are manufactured in labs rather than by natural means. For 10 points each:
answers: “The year in which Ford’s first Model T rolled off his assembly line” [or any description about the Model T hitting the market or selling Model Ts, prompt until you get “Model T”]
parts: Name this book about Bernard and Lenina’s visit to a Savage reservation where they encounter John the Savage.
Brave New World is takes place in 632 A.F. The A.F. refers to the numbers of years after this event occurred. Description acceptable.

Brave New World gets its title from this work. This Shakespearean play has more music than any other of his plays, and composers such as Jean Sibelius, Hector Berlioz, and Engelbert Humperdinck have written incidental music for it.
answers_formatted: “The year in which Ford’s first Model T rolled off his assembly line” [or any description about the Model T hitting the market or selling Model Ts, prompt until you get “Model T”]
acceptable: “The year in which Ford’s first Model T rolled off his assembly line”
any description about the Model T hitting the market
selling Model Ts, prompt until you get “Model T”

bonuses.leadin: When this adjective is used with “cosine,” it denotes the function $\frac{1}{2}(e^{x} + e^{- x})$ [“one-half quantity e to the x plus e to the minus x”]. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this adjective that describes things related to the conic section exemplified by the function f$(x) = \frac{1}{x}$ [“f of x equals one over x”].

Surfaces such as the saddle, which have a hyperbolic geometry, do not satisfy this postulate from Euclid’s Elements, since two lines on such a surface that locally have the namesake property will diverge.
The hyperbolic sine is this type of function, which can be represented mathematically by the relation sinh(-x) = -sinh(x) [“sinch of negative x equals negative sinch of x”].

bonuses.leadin: Many psychological experiments would fail to meet today’s standards of ethics. For 10 points each:
parts: John B. Watson classically conditioned a young boy to associate the beating of a hammer on metal with the presence of this animal, unethically neglecting to rid the boy of his acquired fears.

This series of experiments conducted by Albert Bandura involved conditioning participants to engage in violent behavior after they witnessed the namesake object pop back up every time it was hit or knocked down.
This Swarthmore College psychologist did not receive informed consent in his conformity study in which participants were asked to match the lengths of geometric lines.

bonuses.leadin: A pioneering woman in this occupation worked as a patent clerk before interacting with men in uniform from the Baltimore Riot in 1861. For 10 points each:
parts: Clara Barton adopted this occupation at the onset of the Civil War. Her work in this occupation would later be an inspiration in the formation of the American Red Cross.

Dorothea Dix, another Civil War nurse, rather made her name in the creation of the first generation of these establishments in the mid-1800s. Dix helped create the Harrisburg State Hospital in 1851, Pennsylvania’s first one of these establishments.

This woman also was educated as a nurse; however, she is far better known as a pioneering activist in birth control legislation. This woman’s American Birth Control League later became the Planned Parenthood Federation of America in 1942.

bonuses.leadin: This equation includes the term “R T over z F times the natural log of Q.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this equation named after a German physical chemist, which can be used to calculate quantities associated with half-cell or fuel-cell reactions such as the activity, temperature, and electromotive force.
Oxidation occurs at this end of a cell, in which conventional current flows into a half cell.

A quantity symbolized nu and known as this word prefixed with “over” occurs in variants of the Nernst equation because heat loss makes reactions less efficient. A quantity symbolized mu and known as the “chemical” type of this quantity can be used to derive the Nernst equation.

bonuses.leadin: Types of this thing include Bhoopali, Yaman, and Darbari kanada. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this melodic framework for improvisation that is the Indian Classical equivalent of the Western musical modes.
Rāga occur in this South Indian style of classical music, which is contrasted with Hindustani by its emphasis on vocal expertise.
The drone in both Carnatic and Hindustani music is usually provided by this long-necked plucked instrument that plays buzzing, overtone-rich fifths.

bonuses.leadin: This Aztec Lord of the Night had his right foot replaced with an obsidian mirror. For 10 points each:
answers: Black Tezcatlipoca [do not accept or prompt on Smoking Mirror]
Xipe Totec [do not prompt on Red Tezcatlipoca or the Flayed One]
parts: Name this smoking mirror, who was knocked out of the sky with a stone. This deity then turned into a Jaguar and destroyed that world.
This other deity, known as the Red Tezcatlipoca, was depicted being flayed. People would often touch the flayed skin of those sacrificed to this deity to cure their ailments.
In human sacrifices to Xipe Totec, a sacrificial knife made of obsidian or this fire-producing material was used to remove the victim’s heart and flay them.
answers_formatted: Black Tezcatlipoca [do not accept or prompt on "Smoking Mirror"]
Xipe Totec [do not prompt on Red Tezcatlipoca or the Flayed One]

bonuses.leadin: This physicist co-names an equation with Ludvig Lorenz relating polarizability to a material’s index of refraction. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Dutch Nobel laureate who names the set of transformation equations used in Einstein’s theory of special relativity. He also is the namesake the force felt by a charged particle in an electromagnetic field.
Edward Norton Lorenz lends his name to a particular type of the “strange” version of this thing, a set of chaotic solutions that evolve from varied initial conditions.
Konrad Lorenz helped pioneer the field of modern ethology by studying this instinctive behavior in graylag geese, in which they bond with the first moving object they see after hatching.

bonuses.leadin: While the tradition of the “seven kingdoms” was first established in Henry of Huntingdon’s Historia Anglorum, the first recorded use of this term is from around the 16th century. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this term which described the pre-unification state of the seven Anglo-Saxon kingdoms.
This member of the Heptarchy had its capital at York. Notable kings include Kings Aethelfrith and Oswald.
One king of Northumbria was this man who adopted Roman Christianity. This son of Aethelfrith was the victor at the Battle of Winwaed where he overthrew Penda of Mercia.

bonuses.leadin: This character refuses to answer her father when she and her two sisters are to proclaim their love. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character who chooses to stay silent and receive no land, unlike Regan and Goneril.
This king dies in Cordelia’s arms, and also gives his name to the play in which he appears.

In a similar work by the Brothers Grimm, the elder daughters flatter the king, while the youngest brings him a decorated container of this substance. The king was so sad that she only loved him more than this substance that he demanded her execution.

bonuses.leadin: This American pop artist publicly spoke about AIDs and homosexuality on many occasions. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this artist behind works such as Crack is Wack, Boxers, and Ignorance=Fear. He was known for using stick-figure-like people in his works.
Haring’s work Boxers was a work of this artform. Other famous examples of this include Cloud Gate and an untitled work known as the Chicago Picasso.
The Chicago Picasso depicts a single one of these body-parts at its center. The Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer I features the titular woman with a dress covered in these.

bonuses.leadin: This story ends when the narrator refuses to listen to a story about a one-eyed, stubby-tailed cow. For 10 points each:
answers: “The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County” [or “The Notorious Jumping Frog of Calaveras County”, or “Jim Smiley and His Jumping Frog”]
parts: Name this short story in which Simon Wheeler tells the story of the title animal named Dan’l Webster, who does not budge when a stranger pours lead shot into his mouth.

In this short story, an unnamed Manhattan lawyer tells the story of the title character, who begins working as a legal document copier along with Nippers and Turkey and eventually responds to everybody’s requests by saying, “I would prefer not to.”
In this short story by Bret Harte, Oakhurst, Stumpy, and other gold prospectors raise a baby boy whose mother dies in childbirth, but that boy eventually dies along with Kentuck in a flash flood.
answers_formatted: “The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County” [or “The Notorious Jumping Frog of Calaveras County”, or “Jim Smiley and His Jumping Frog”]
acceptable: “The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County”
“The Notorious Jumping Frog of Calaveras County”,

bonuses.leadin: This man failed his suicide attempt because the cyanide he swallowed only induced vomiting, and the river he jumped into was only 13 centimeters deep. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this member of the Black Hand who failed to assassinate Franz Ferdinand, and blew up the car behind him instead.
This eventual assassin of Franz Ferdinand was unable to act after the initial failure by Cabrinovic. He was imprisoned and eventually died of tuberculosis in his cell.
The assassination took place in this city. Military troops from this city supposedly were not present because it would offend the local citizenry.

bonuses.leadin: 50% of citizens in the city of Punta Arenas, located in this country, are considered ethnically Croat. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this South American nation home to a majority of the Atacama Desert, with its capital at Santiago.

Chile maintains possession of this distant Pacific Island known as Isla de Pascua in Spanish. The introduction of the Polynesian rat is in part responsible for the massive decline in the indigenous population on this island.

This city, aside from being the country’s fifth most populated metropolitan area, was home to Chile’s first public library and the longest continuously published Spanish newspaper. This city is also the name of a Lutheran university in northeastern Indiana with a crusader as a mascot.

bonuses.leadin: This man spoke against consumerism and environmental degradation in his encyclical Laudato si. For 10 points each:
answers: resignation from the papacy [or stepping down or equivalents] <McMaken>
parts: Name this current Bishop of Rome who is the first Jesuit Pope and the first Pope from the Americas.
Pope Francis was the Archbishop of the capital city of this country. The Metropolitan Cathedral in that city also houses the remains of General José de San Martín.
Pope Francis was elected by the conclave after this action occurred with Pope Benedict XVI [“the sixteenth”] in 2013. This action has not happened since 1415 with Pope Gregory XII [“the twelfth”].
answers_formatted: resignation from the papacy [or stepping down or equivalents]

bonuses.leadin: Ho Chi Minh opened the Declaration of Independence for Vietnam with this line. For 10 points each:
answers: “all men are created equal” [exact answer required]
parts: Give this five-word phrase from the U.S. Declaration of Independence that is said to be a self-evident truth.
Ho Chi Minh convinced this emperor to abdicate. This last emperor of Vietnam also was responsible for officially adopting the name “Vietnam,” formally replacing “Annam.”
Bao Dai was the final emperor of this final ruling family of Vietnam. Other members of this dynasty include Gia Long and Minh Mang.
answers_formatted: “all men are created equal” [exact answer required]

bonuses.leadin: The Planctae, or wandering rocks, were one example of these mythological things. For 10 points each:
answers: it was anchored in place [accept anything about it not being able to move] <Yoshida>
parts: Name these things, other examples of which include Naxos and Milos.
Another famous mythological island is this island, upon which Leto gave birth to Artemis and Apollo. It was mostly barren.
After Leto gave birth, this fate befell Delos. Description acceptable.
answers_formatted: it was anchored in place [accept anything about it not being able to move]
acceptable: anything about it not being able to move

bonuses.leadin: A population’s net rate reaches its net death rate if this quantity is reached. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this maximal load of a population in a local environment, which in population dynamics is symbolized K.

In contrast to K-selection, species that exhibit this form of selection exploit less-crowded ecological niches and produce many offspring that have lower chances of survival. The name for this type of selection refers to the term in the Verhulst model that describes the maximum growth rate.
The aforementioned Verhulst model consists of a differential equation describing this type of curve. This function, a type of sigmoid curve, runs from zero to the carrying capacity in an “S” shape.

bonuses.leadin: The main character of this story proclaims that “if I had plenty of land, I shouldn’t fear the Devil himself,” upon which Satan accepts his challenge. For 10 points each:
answers: “How Much Land Does a Man Need?” [or “How Much Land Does a Man Require?” or “Mnoga li cheloveku zemli nuzhna?”]
falling while hanging up his curtains [prompt gratuitously and be lenient] <Yoshida>
parts: Name this short story in which Pahom needs to walk around as large an area as he can, so long as he returns to the starting point by sundown. In the end, he runs so hard that he drops dead.
“How Much Land Does a Man Need?” was a story by this man, the author of novellas such as Hadji Murad and The Death of Ivan Ilyich.
In The Death of Ivan Ilyich, Ilyich is a judge with a terminal illness who dies when performing this activity. Description acceptable.
answers_formatted: “How Much Land Does a Man Need?” [or “How Much Land Does a Man Require?” or “Mnoga li cheloveku zemli nuzhna?”]
falling while hanging up his curtains [prompt gratuitously and be lenient]
acceptable: “How Much Land Does a Man Need?”
“How Much Land Does a Man Require?”
falling while hanging up his curtains

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about musical compositions completed by others, for 10 points each:
parts: This last work by Mozart was completed by his student, Franz Xaver Sussmayr.
This last opera by Puccini, whose most famous aria is “Nessun Dorma,” was completed by Franco Alfano.
This grand opera by Alexander Borodin was completed by Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov and Alexander Glazunov.
